Dialogue.Stage Direction: There are screams outside the radio room. A crewman dashes in and starts broadcasting.

Dialogue.Line: Mayday. Mayday. SS
Pevensey Castle. We're being attacked!
Give your position, please. Give your position.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The base commander, Captain Hart, enters from outside the complex as Bowman tries to listen through the static.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
It's a Mayday, sir. SS Pevensey Castle, they say they're being attacked.
We're abandoning ship! We're abandoning ship! Our position is

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A scaly hand takes the microphone. The crewman backs away then screams.
The Doctor and Jo are being ferried to a small island in an even smaller boat.

Dialogue.Line: That's it over there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks through a pair of binoculars at what is really Norris Castle on the Isle of Wight.

Dialogue.Line: There you are, Jo. That's the Master's permanent residence from now on.
Well, let's hope he's still there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They moor up and walk along the jetty.

Dialogue.Line: Okay.
I'll be back in a couple of hours to take you over to the mainland.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Robbins wheels a small motorbike while the Doctor and Jo get into a stripped out Citroen 2CV with no doors.
In the castle, an older man picks up the internal telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Yes?
Main gate. Two visitors for the prisoner, sir, from UNIT. Passes all in order, sir.
Right, send them up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jo are let in through the gate and showed up to the office by an armed guard. Trenchard is working at his desk.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I suppose we could always come back later,
Oh, yes, of course. You'll be the chappie from UNIT.
My name's Josephine Grant. How do you do? And this is the Doctor.
Colonel Trenchard. Delighted to meet you. Pleasant trip?
Yes, thank you.
You're late, you know?
Yes, we were held up.
Mmm, thought you might have sunk without trace.
Sunk?
Happens all the time recently.
What does?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Trenchard gives a piece of paper to the guard, who leaves with it.

Dialogue.Line: Ships vanishing. Makes you think, doesn't it?
It does indeed.
Now then, passes?
Well, look, we've been through all that, actually.
We don't take any chances here. Let's see them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo hands them over.

Dialogue.Line: Oh. Ah, yes, from UNIT.
That's right, yes.
Yes. Ah, jolly good. Well, you'll be wanting to see the prisoner.
That was the general idea.
He's an interesting chap, you know. You'll enjoy talking to him.
If ever I get the opportunity. Has he given you any trouble as yet?
Not a bit.
You've got to be joking! He must have tried to escape?
You've seen our security precautions. Anyway, we're on an island.
Has he tried to hypnotise any of the guards, by any chance?
He couldn't. All our men are completely immune to hypnotism.
How can you be so sure?
Prove it to you. (into intercom) Trenchard here. Send that new man, Wilson, in to see the prisoner. Now then, come over here and take a look into this screen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The monitor shows the Master sitting and reading.

Dialogue.Line: My word, he's putting on weight.
Poor chap, he can't get the exercise. Now then, watch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Closer to a hotel room than a prison cell. There are even some carvings for decoration. The guard enters.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Trenchard sent me, sir, to see if you wanted your book changed.
Well, that's very kind of him, but I haven't quite finished yet.
Right you are, sir.
Just a minute. You're new here, aren't you?
Arrived yesterday, sir.
Wait. Do you know who I am?
You're the prisoner.
I am the Master. Come here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wilson walks towards the Master, who rises to look him in the eyes.

Dialogue.Line: I am the Master and you will obey me. You understand? You will obey me.
You'll let us know when you've finished with the book, sir?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wilson leaves.

Dialogue.Line: You see?
Yes, very impressive. Perhaps we could see him now, yes?
Certainly. This way. After you, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Trenchard leads the way along a corridor to the cell and enters. The Master is now working out on a rowing machine.

Dialogue.Line: Visitors for you.

Well, as you see, very well. Trying to keep fit.
Yes, well, I'll leave you all together. Give the guard a shout when you want to leave.
Thank you, Colonel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Trenchard leaves.

Dialogue.Line: He's quite a decent sort, really. Used to be the Governor of a colony once, so he tells me.
Very small colony, wasn't it? In fact, I believe they claimed independence soon after he arrived.
He seems to be looking after you very well.
Oh, yes, I've got everything I want, except, of course, my freedom.
You can consider yourself lucky. Quite a few people were in favour of having you executed.
My dear Doctor, don't think I'm not grateful. I've had a chance to think about things while I've been in here.
Have you now?
I wish that something like this had happened a long time ago.
Surely you don't like being locked up?
No, but, it's given me a chance to reconsider my life.
Am I to take it that you're a changed man?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master washes his hands in the en-suite.

Dialogue.Line: Is that so very incredible? After all, I do have a great deal of which to repent.
You're telling us.

So that you could use it in order to escape from this planet, Doctor?
No, so that I can make absolutely certain that you can't.
No, I'm sorry. That is too much to ask.
Ask a silly question. Come on, Jo. I think we'd better be going. Is there anything that I can do for you at all?
There is one thing. Please come in now and then to have a chat. Oh, Trenchard's a very nice man, but his conversation is somewhat limited.
Goodbye.
Goodbye, Miss Grant. And goodbye, Doctor. I sincerely hope we meet again very soon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor nearly shakes the Master's hand, but turns the gesture into a wave.

Dialogue.Line: Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master gets back on his rowing machine, laughing.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Mmm?
You felt sorry for him, didn't you. You wanted to come down here and see that was all right.
Well, he used to be a friend of mine once. A very good friend. In fact, you might almost say we were at school together.
How long's he going to be here?
Forever, I should think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Trenchard enters.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, ready for off, then? I'd better stamp your passes.
What, again?
Got to be checked in and out, old man. It's the rule. Well, we don't look after him too badly, do we?
No, indeed. But I advise you to be careful. He's a very dangerous man.
Ah, don't worry. I keep my eye on him. There you are, my dear. Come along now then.
Thank you.
I'll get one of my chaps to run you down to the quayside.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Trenchard enters. The Master is doing a crossword. Times, probably.

Dialogue.Line: There we are, then. Fooled them nicely, didn't we?
I hope so.
What about that hypnotism wheeze, eh? That took them in.
Don't underestimate the Doctor. Do you really believe that he came here to see me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master takes a dictionary from a bookcase to help with his crossword.

Dialogue.Line: Why else?
Vanishing ships, of course.
Oh, I don't think so. No, he didn't seem particularly interested when I mentioned it.
You did what!
We were just chatting. No harm done, surely.
Let's hope not. By the way, what about those admiralty charts I asked for?
They'll be here this afternoon.
Ah, splendid. Er, there is one more thing.
Yes?
I wonder, do you think I could have another television set? For the bedroom.
Yes. Yes, I'm sure that's possible.
Colour, of course.
Of course! Well, if you'll excuse me?
Ah, it's true. Three ships vanished. Something queer going on for all their trying to hush it up.
Well, who's trying to hush it up?
Well, them over at the naval base. The secret research establishment.
You seem to know a great deal about all this.
Well, I'm in the lifeboat crew, aren't I? We went out to look for survivors. Only found the one lifeboat, capsized. The bottom was all charred in a sort of pattern.
Well, where's this boat now?
Ah, the navy took it. Told us to keep our mouths shut.
Well, where's this naval base, then?
Over beyond the headland.
Right, well, perhaps you'd like to take me there straight away.
Mister Trenchard paid me to bring you out here and take you back. You want to go over to the naval base, then you make your own arrangements.
Yes, well, you're probably perfectly right. Look, er, I wonder whether you'd like to go and see what's happening to my young friend? She said she was going to buy some picture postcards.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds up a note of the realm.

Dialogue.Line: I don't mind.
I'd go myself, only my bad leg's playing me up a bit. The Crimea, you know.
I see. Crimea?
Oh, Gallipoli? El Alamein? Does it really matter?
I reckon not.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Robbins takes the money and leaves. The Doctor unties the little boat, starts up the engine and chugs away.
At HMS Seaspite Naval Research Establishment, Captain Hart is giving dictation to his secretary, a young Wren.

Dialogue.Line: And I regret to inform your Lordships that our investigations have failed to reveal any clue as to the cause of the sinkings, full stop. The charred ship's lifeboat will be sent to our laboratory at HMS Vernon Portsmouth for investigation and analysis. Meanwhile, we are keeping careful watch.
Yes, sir?
Come and look at this. What on Earth?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is steering the boat up onto the beach.

Dialogue.Line: Perhaps he's lost, sir.
This place is supposed to be top secret. People treating it like Brighton beach.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart picks up a telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Get me the Master at Arms. Captain Hart here. I don't know whether you've noticed but there happens to be a stray civilian chugging into the base! Get on to it, will you?
Sir, he's making straight for the lifeboat!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor crunches his way over the shingle to an upturned boat and gets out his magnifying glass to examine the burn marks.

Dialogue.Line: Oy! You!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master at Arms leads five armed ratings at the double.

Dialogue.Line: Good afternoon. I wonder whether I could see your commanding officer?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo gives Robbins a ten pound note.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, Miss.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Robbins gives Jo his motorcycle helmet.

Dialogue.Line: Look after it for me, won't you?
Don't worry. I'll bring it back just as soon as I've found the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo rides off on his motorcycle.

Only puppets, you know? For children.
Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master spreads the chart on the table.

Dialogue.Line: That's right. Thank you. Now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master plots points on the chart.

Ah. What are you doing?
I've just been plotting the sightings of the three sinkings. There, there and there. And it's interesting that right in the middle of them, there's this abandoned sea fort.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The marked Fort is just off Fortress Island.

Dialogue.Line: Not abandoned any more, old chap.
Really?
Hart's people are going to use it as a sonar testing station. Contractors are working on the place now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Inside No Man's Land Sea Fort in the middle of the Solent, two men are playing cards and drinking from cans.

Dialogue.Line: How much to see you?
A fiver.
Right.
Full house. Kings on twos.
Oh, that's marvellous, innit. Just marvellous.
Come on, it's not your life savings, it's only a couple of quid. I'll give you a chance to get your own back.
Ah, forget it.
What's the matter with you?
I don't know. Being stuck out here, I suppose.
It's not so bad. Are you sure you don't want another game?
Do you know, there's something funny about this place.
Share the joke.
Well, the place is deserted, right?
So?
Just the two of us on maintenance?
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Possibly by the owner of the scaly hand reaching over a hatch ledge.

Oh? Why?

Well, of course I have.
Then you must have noticed the linear nature of those scorch marks. Excuse me, my dear. May I?

Dialogue.Line: Now then, sit down. Now, the marks are a very definite shape, a linear shape like this. Now, how do you account for that?

Dialogue.Line: A freak affect if the ship caught fire.

A concentrated beam of heat, applied from underneath the boat whilst it was still in the water.

Those are the last known positions of the missing vessels so far as we can estimate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blythe answers the telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Captain Hart's office? Yes. Yes, I see. Hold on. There's a young lady here with two UNIT passes. She wants to know if there's anyone here called the Doctor?

Forget it. It's not your problem. Black or white?

Fat load of use you are.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, well, these passes appear to be in order. You may go.

That fort is being converted for use as a testing station. There's nobody there but a couple of maintenance workmen.
Nevertheless, it is right in the centre of all the trouble, isn't it? Now if some of your naval bods could get me out there, Captain?
Doctor, I have no authority to provide naval vessels for your pleasure jaunts.
Look, don't you realise how important this is?
I realise only too well. Three ships have been sunk and many lives have been lost. Now, if you don't mind?
Doctor, I think he wants us to go.
I suggest that you take your theories along to your own people at UNIT and put the whole thing on an official level.
If Horatio Nelson had been in charge of this operation, I hardly think that he would have waited for official instructions.
Yes, a pretty impulsive fellow, if one can believe the history books.
History books? Captain Hart, Horatio Nelson was a personal friend of mine. Come on, Jo.
Good grief. Poor chap's as mad as a hatter.

Up that ladder. Now hold tight, Jo. We're coming alongside now.

The Doctor and Jo walk down a metal staircase.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It is Clark armed with a wrench. He raises it to attack.

Dialogue.Line: Stop! We're friends! Stop!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs Clark's arm and makes him drop the wrench.

Dialogue.Line: Hickman! He's dead! They killed him! Came from the sea. The sea. A sea devil!

It's all right.
We've got to get him into that cabin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo and the Doctor half-carry Clark back the way they came.

Dialogue.Line: Hickman.
Come on. All right.
Monster.
Yes.
Sea devil.
Now, easy.
Hickman.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The reptile watches them go.

Dialogue.Line: The sea monster.
Yeah, come on, don't worry. Get yourself down here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clark lies down on the lower bunk bed.

Dialogue.Line: That's right. Mind your head. Mind yourself.
That's it.
Hickman.
Shush.
Where's your radio? The radio, where is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clark points across the room.

Dialogue.Line: Over here?
Hickman.
Shush.
Ripped it out. They took it away.
Yes, they certainly did.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the First Aid box.

Dialogue.Line: Devil. Sea monster. Monster.
Yes, yes, yes.
Now, listen to me Take this swab, Jo. Swab his arm. Now, are there are more transmitters on this fort?
No, nothing.
Any transistor radios, that sort of thing?
I think so. The crew's quarters. The crew.
What do you want to do? Listen to Night Ride?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A popular BBC Radio 2 show.

Dialogue.Line: It is possible to turn a receiver into a transmitter, you know.
It is?

Yes, it's simply a matter of modulating the signal. You connect the output of your loudspeaker into the input of your low frequency amplifier, then you connect the output of your low frequency amplifier into your oscillator. You use your loudspeaker as a microphone and there you are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor fills a hypodermic with liquid.

Dialogue.Line: Ah.
Now, where exactly are these transistor radios?
Crew's quarters, down the corridor, next deck.
All right. Thank you. Now don't worry, this is not going to hurt you. All right? Now you'll soon be all right.
Hickman.
Soon feel better. Look after him, will you, Jo?
Yes. Shush. Come on now, try and relax. Come on. That's it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and a reptile startle each other.

Dialogue.Line: Don't be alarmed. I've no wish to harm you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The reptile raises its 'hand' which is holding a disc-like device.

Dialogue.Line: Now, wait. We must talk.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A bolt of red energy just misses the Doctor as he ducks. The Doctor runs up the staircase and the reptile follows. The chase goes up and down ladders.

Dialogue.Line: How do you feel now? Would you like a nice hot cup of tea with some sugar, hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs in and bolts the door.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drags the table over to bar the door.

Dialogue.Line: Wire?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor find the end of a long wire and goes over to the junction box.

Dialogue.Line: What is going on?
Just as I thought. Reptiles, like those creatures in the caves. It's completely hostile. Here, hang on to this. Tight! Hang on.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The other end of the wire has crocodile clips.

Dialogue.Line: Well, now what are you doing?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor fastens the clips to the door bolts then returns to the junction box.

Dialogue.Line: Those creatures can cut through anything. Rock, metal, anything.
Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The metal door is starting to melt. A green hand reaches through the hole and gropes for the bolts. The Doctor throws the power switch and it screams, pulling its hand back. He turns the power off again.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. Give me a hand.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls the table back and unbolts the door.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we going?
We've got to get after that creature. Now, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They chase it through the fort until it jumps out of a broken window into the sea.
WRNS Blythe is on the phone.

Dialogue.Line: Keep trying.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart enters.

Dialogue.Line: Morning, Blythe.
Good morning, sir.
Anything in?

Oh, no.
He and the girl were seen heading out to sea yesterday afternoon. There's been no sign of them since.
Well, get onto the fort and see if they've wound up there.
I've already done that, sir. The fort just wasn't answering. I can't raise them at all.
Well, we'd better take a look around. Get me Air Sea Rescue.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Sea King takes off.

Dialogue.Line: How's it going?
Nearly finished. Just about to test it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has been working on a transistor radio.

Dialogue.Line: Hmm, I've seen things like that in a modern art exhibition. You don't honestly think you can transmit with it, do you?
Certainly I do. I'll prove it to you. Right, here goes.

Hey there, early birds, we've got a wonderful batch of discs for you this morning! So, don't feel isolated and cut off from the world. Whoever you are, wherever you are, we've got something just for you!
Hey, that was my favourite DJ.
I think I must have got me wires crossed somewhere.
Here's your tea.
Thanks.
Doctor?
Mmm?
Those things that attacked us. You said you'd seen something like it before.
Something very similar, certainly. They emerged from some caves in Derbyshire.
The Silurians, wasn't it? The Brigadier was telling me.
That's a complete misnomer. The chap who discovered them must have got the period wrong. No, properly speaking, they should have been called the Eocenes.
That was that race of super reptiles that had been in hibernation for billions of years, wasn't it?
That's right, and if you want my opinion, there's another of their colony right here beneath us.
Well, something seems to have woken them up.
Probably the rebuilding of this fort.
But I thought you said they lived in caves?
Well, this is a different species, completely adapted to life underwater.
And they've been sinking this ships?
Very likely.
Why? I mean, why are they so hostile? What have we done to them?

They still think of Earth as their planet, Jo, and they want it back. As far as they're concerned, man is just an ape who got above himself. Right, I think that should do it. Let's have another go. Hello, hello. Mayday, Mayday, Mayday! This is, er, this, er, this is. What is this? What's our call sign?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo reads the note on the wall above where the radio used to be.

Dialogue.Line: Oscar Bravo Tango Seven Four.

Hello, Mayday, Mayday, Mayday, this is Oscar Bravo Tango Seven Four. We are stranded on this fort and have a wounded man here. Can you send immediate assistance? Can you hear me? Can you hear me? Over.
Oh Doctor, you don't think you'll get through to anybody on that old lash- up, do you?
Hello, Oscar Bravo Tango, am receiving you loud and clear. Am about to land. Over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Helicopter rotors can be heard overhead.

Dialogue.Line: It works!
Hello, Oscar Bravo Tango speaking. Who are you? Who are you? Over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo runs outside to look through a window.

Dialogue.Line: It's a helicopter!
Yes. Well, though I say so myself, I think that's a remarkably efficient piece of work.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And the set goes Bang!
Trenchard enters with a guard who is carrying a large box.

Dialogue.Line: Right, put it over there. Here we are then.
Splendid!
None too easy, you know, getting hold of something like this at a moments notice. Had to send one of my chaps to the mainland. Said it was for theatricals.
How very ingenious.
Nothing to it. Just have to use the old loaf, you know. When do we leave?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master is wearing a naval officer's cap.

Dialogue.Line: As soon as possible.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart enters with the Doctor and Jo.

Dialogue.Line: How can I go to the Admiralty with a story like that? Sea Devils. If only you had some proof.

Yes. Get on to sickbay, will you? See if he's conscious yet.
Sickbay, please. Oh hello, Captain Hart's secretary
Even you must admit that something happened on that fort!
Well, perhaps one of them went berserk and attacked the other one.
But we saw it too, remember?
You may. Well, Blythe?
He's still delirious and he's babbling something about sea devils.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A prison guard drives Trenchard into HMS Seaspite and parks up. Actually HMS St George, Portsmouth

Dialogue.Line: You can go to the Petty Officer's mess. I'll send for you later.
Very good, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard leaves. Trenchard looks around then knocks on the side of the car and walks away. The Master comes out from underneath a rug in the back dressed in a Lieutenant Commander's uniform. A squad of ratings marches past.

Dialogue.Line: Squad, eyes right!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master salutes.

Dialogue.Line: Eyes front! About turn! Squad, halt!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master walks off into the base, saluting another group of sailors on his way.

Dialogue.Line: (into phone) Well, did he say why he wanted to see me? Oh, all right, you'd better send him up. All right then, Doctor, let's assume that I accept the existence of these Sea Devils. What do you want me to do?
Well, to begin with, we must make every effort to make contact with them.
But you claim that they're responsible for sinking the ships.
It may still be possible to find a peaceful solution. We're not dealing with animals, Captain Hart, we're dealing with intelligent beings.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a knock on the door and Trenchard enters.

Dialogue.Line: Have you got a minute, old chap? Ah, thanks very much. Want a word with you about the golf tournament. Good heavens!
Colonel Trenchard.
Doctor. Miss Grant. Thought you two'd left the island yesterday.
Well, we didn't quite manage to get away.
Taking a look round the island? Charming spot, isn't it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart clears his throat loudly.

Dialogue.Line: Er, sorry to bother you, John, old man, but it's about the weekend. We are rather relying on you, you know.
Of course I'll do my best, but if we get a bit of a flap on, then
That's just what I was thinking, so perhaps it would be as well if I arranged to have a reserve standing by.
Yes, why don't you do that, Colonel? Captain Hart is likely to be very busy from now on.
Yes, life is rather full at the moment, George.

Submarine indicator buoys still won't release, sir.
All right, Summers. Radio Captain Hart the moment you surface. Tell him we're immobilised on the sea bed by some unknown force and intruders have broken through the hull.
Aye, aye, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Summers is in an immersion suit, ready to escape the seabed.

Dialogue.Line: You've checked your R/T?
Yes, sir.
All right, carry on. Good luck.
Something's happening to this door, sir. It's getting hot.
Right, small arms, Number One.
Aye, aye, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mitchell unbars and unlocks a cupboard.

Dialogue.Line: Forward hatch is jammed, sir.
All right, Summers.
Johnson, here. Petty Officer, here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Small automatic weapons are handed out from the cupboard as a bulkhead starts to melt.

Dialogue.Line: Right, take cover.
The door's going!
All right, Number One. Hold your fire until we see what they are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A reptile comes through the molten remains of the bulkhead.

Dialogue.Line: I just can't take it in. It's all too much for me.
Trenchard, you really must be more calm. Believe me, it's very simple.
Simple? You've misled me all along. You said it was spies, saboteurs. You said we'd catch them.
Look, if I had talked to you about sea monsters, would you have believed me?
I've risked everything to help you and you've lied to me.
I had to lie. Now sit down, Trenchard. Sit down and listen to me.
I don't know how you can be so calm.

Now listen, that creature that you saw is one of a race of intelligent reptiles that has a deadly hatred of mankind. Now somehow, they've established themselves in the sea, but now they intend to emerge and conquer the Earth.
What? We must warn the authorities at once!
No, no. Premature action would ruin everything.
What else can we do?
Wait until this device of mine is perfected, and then tell the authorities.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jo run out from the trees and take cover behind a large shrub at the sound of voices.

Dialogue.Line: Hold still. Hold still.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One guard on horseback, and two vehicles, come careering down the slope and past them.

Dialogue.Line: Right. We've got to get back to Captain Hart. Come on.
They're not in the beach sector. We've completely lost track of them.
Trenchard, if they reach the naval base
Exactly. They'll tell Hart everything.
Mind you, there's a good chance that he won't believe them, of course.
But suppose he does? Suppose he turns up here again?
Refuse to admit him.
Don't be ridiculous!
Trenchard, you are running a top security establishment here. Your only responsibility is to the government.
What about the Doctor? He'll report to UNIT. They can go to the government.
Now look, you must trust me a little longer. I assure you all your troubles will soon be over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The submarine is once again underway. Ridgeway is plotting a course on one map then walks over to the chart table.

Dialogue.Line: Aft end flange space dry of water, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The reptile takes Ridgeway's hand and points it to the Sea Fort on another chart.

Dialogue.Line: Why there?
Ask Green Gilbert.
All right, old man. Get you there in no time! Er, sir, shall we take a look at the pressure gauge, sir?
If you'll excuse me one moment?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ridgeway and Mitchell go over to the periscope area.

Dialogue.Line: Sir, shouldn't we try and jump them?
No.
You mean we're going to do nothing at all?
Sooner or later, these things are going to return to their base. I want to know where that is. Starboard twenty, Number One.
I'm sorry if I seem to be repeating myself, Doctor, but I don't believe a word of it!
Well, I can assure you we didn't walk ten miles across open countryside just to tell you fairy stories.
Monsters coming out of the sea.
But it's different this time. Everybody saw it. Even Trenchard and the guards.
And you think Trenchard will confirm your story?
I doubt it. The Master's got some sort of hold over him.
The Doctor's seen these creatures before.
Oh, I'm quite sure he has, Miss Grant.
In some caves in Derbyshire. You see, they want to take over the Earth
Oh, really, Miss Grant, if you think for one moment I'm going to believe
Well, re-take if you like, and what they're going to do is
All right, Jo, all right, all right. Let me deal with the explanations. Look, it's like this

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blythe enters with a plate of sandwiches for Jo.

Dialogue.Line: Only cheese, I'm afraid. The best the steward could do.
Oh, that's super. Thanks very much.
For heaven's sakes, Jo. What do you think this is, a picnic?
All right, well let's forget about the Sea Devils. What about Trenchard trying to take us prisoners then?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor eats Jo's sandwiches.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I only have your word for that, haven't I?
All right, what about the theft of your electronic spares? Surely you'll agree that happened?
Since I was here at the time, yes.
The Master stole those parts to make his calling device, and
His what?
Well, he's developed some way of communicating with them. Probably a ultra-high frequency sonic beam. These are rather good. Want one?
No, thank you.
Sandwich?
Thank you.
Doctor!
Oh, I'm so sorry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo is left with the lettuce garnish. The telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Captain Hart's office? Oh, I see. Yes, yes, I'll tell him. They've had to abandon the search, sir. They'll start again at first light.
Very well.
I'll get you some more sandwiches.
Thanks very much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blythe leaves.

Dialogue.Line: How overdue is the submarine?
Four hours.
It should never have been sent, you know. They were bound to presume it was hostile.
Kindly leave the naval side of the operation to me, Doctor.
Captain Hart, you are dealing with a situation completely outside of your own experience. And if you won't let me help you
All right then, Doctor. What do you want me to do?
Well, the key to this whole situation is at the castle.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bowman puts his head round the door to the radio room.

Dialogue.Line: Sir, I think we've got something.
Where?
There, sir. Contact bearing two seven zero. Range, twenty thousand yards. Heading zero four seven.
The submarine?
Could be.
I think it must be, sir.
You see where the thing's heading? That beach by castle! Perhaps you'll believe me now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master has his device running on yet another frequency, that sounds like very speeded up speech. Then he switches off, taps at a bank of eight keys and switches on again. Off, more keying, and Trenchard enters.

Dialogue.Line: That thing working all right?
It still needs a few minor adjustments, that's all.
Look, I've been giving some thought to all this. It's going to be an enormous job coping with these creatures. We must give the authorities all the notice we can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The device emits more speeded up speech and the Master unplugs it.

Dialogue.Line: What was that?
Just random feedback. It's nothing important.
Sounded like some sort of message.
Look, Trenchard, I am trying to carry out a very difficult and complex task here, and I can't work if I'm being continually interrupted.
I'm terribly sorry, old chap. I'll leave you to it.
Thank you.

Yes. (Trenchard leaves. The Master plugs the machine back in and the message comes tumbling out. He smiles. Under cover of darkness, six reptiles are walking through the surf to the shore. Further out, six more are emerging from the depths.)

(into phone) I tell you I must speak to the Minister. It's most important. Well, when do you expect him back? No, I can't tell you what's wrong. The security of the nation is at risk. Oh, very well, I'll hold on, but please hurry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In a corridor, a guard spots a melted lock and looks at it. A reptile grabs him from behind and breaks his neck.

Dialogue.Line: (into phone) No, it can't wait till the morning. Oh, you'll have to interrupt his meeting. This is a matter of national urgency. Oh, very well, as soon as he's free then. But if there's any unnecessary delay, believe me, you'll answer for it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Trenchard turns on the monitor and watches the Master tapping the keys on his device. He turns it off and picks up an internal telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Guard? (Elsewhere, a telephone smashes on the floor and a guard falls next to it. Trenchard unlocks a drawer in his desk and takes out his service revolver, checking that it is loaded.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A patrol of two guards encounter two reptiles in a corridor, and one man manages to set off the alarm. Guards and Trenchard run through corridors, guns at the ready. Reptiles kill two guards and make their way through the building to the Master's cell. Trenchard comes across Drew firing at something.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening, man?
They're all over the place, sir! They killed most of the lads!
Who? Who's attacking us?
Lizards, sir. Like that thing we saw on the beach. Come on, sir. They were after me.
Pull yourself together, man. Have you sent for help?
But it's no good, sir!
There's a direct line to Whitehall in my office. Use that.
Why can't you, sir?
I shall attend to the security of my prisoner. Go on, man. Move!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drew leaves. Trenchard faces three reptiles and empties his revolver into one of them, which clutches its chest. The clock on the wall says it is just after 9.00 when the Master stops sending his message, and the three reptiles enter his cell. Trenchard lies dead on the floor outside.
Bowman has been sending a morse signal.

Dialogue.Line: No, it's no good, sir. Nothing.
Well, if that thing was the submarine, why don't they answer your signals?
Perhaps they can't.
Tell the search coordinator to check that area immediately. It'll be light soon.
Sir.
Sir, contact fading.
What?
Captain Hart, we've got to find out what's happening at that castle.
Contact lost.
I want an armed party and two Land Rovers at the main gate in four minutes flat. Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two Navy Land Rovers arrive.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. Follow in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The group come across a dead guard.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He has spotted Trenchard's body.

Dialogue.Line: I don't understand why.
The Master had no further use for him, that's why.
But why did he help the Master in the first place?
What would you say was Trenchard's strongest characteristic?
Oh, I don't know. Patriotism, I suppose.
Exactly. And the Master used that patriotism as a weapon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bowman is filling in a message form when Blythe enters with a mug.

Dialogue.Line: I've bought you some kai.
Roger, search force. Over and out. Did you get through to Captain Hart?
I telephoned the castle but they've already left.
Well, they're definitely getting an echo and the object's moving.
I see.
What is it, Bowman? Have they re-established contact?
It's a message from one of the search vessels, sir. They are getting an echo.
The submarine?
Yes, it's moving towards the fort now. Moving at about thirty knots.
Depth?
Steady at one five zero feet.
The fort. Look, Captain Hart, can you lay on a diving vessel?
Yes, the Reclaim's standing by on the search. But why?
I want to inspect the sea bed at the base of that fort.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jo are ferried out in a launch to the Royal Navy's diving and search ship, A23, who sadly no longer exists. The Doctor is piped aboard. and they go down to the diver's section where the tanks and dry suits are kept.

Dialogue.Line: All pre-dive checks completed?
Yes. sir.
Doctor, are you quite sure you want to go through with this?
Yes, positive.
Ready to lower the observation chamber?
Yes, sir. The crew is standing by. We'll send a man down with him.
Good.
If you don't mind, I'd rather go down on my own.
Well, I presume you're a trained diver in addition to your other accomplishments then, Doctor?
Naturally. What's more, I know these creatures. I've encountered them before so I know what I'm looking for.
All right, carry on.
Aye, aye, sir.
Doctor?
What is it, Jo?
Is it really necessary for you to go down?
How else am I going to make contact?
Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The diving bell is waiting, hanging from its crane on deck.

Dialogue.Line: Well, good luck, Doctor.
Thank you, Captain Hart.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor climbs up into the bell.

Dialogue.Line: Everything okay, sir?
Yes, thank you, Chief. C.P.O: Very good.
Test the links.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The crew make their final checks and then the crane hoists the bell over the side.

Dialogue.Line: Pull up the links. Carry on lowering.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The bell enters the water.

Dialogue.Line: Twelve feet.
Carry on lowering.
Let me speak to him. How's it going, Doctor? DOCTOR [on monitor]: Splendid, thank you. A most interesting trip.
You'll reach seabed in a few minutes. Tell us immediately if anything goes wrong. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Don't worry. I'll be all right.
You have reached seabed. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Right.
Are you all right, Doctor?
Yes, I'm fine, thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor peers out of a porthole.

Dialogue.Line: Hang on a minute!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And a reptile peers in.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right, Doctor? Shall we bring you up? DOCTOR [on monitor]: Definitely not! I think I've just (static)
Bring him up!
Start winches! Hoist SCC!
He's gone!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Somewhere else, a much smaller and very alien diving bell is being lowered in the Sea Devils base. Watching the operation is one reptile wearing a fishnet cloak as well as the tunic. It gestures and a plug is removed from the side of the bell, dragging cables out with it, and revealing the Doctor's face.
A man in camel hair coat and bowler hat enters.

Dialogue.Line: Good morning, my dear. Captain Hart here?
No sir, he's at sea.
Well, I suppose that's the right place for a sailor, eh? What's your name?
Blythe, sir.
Walker. Parliamentary Private Secretary. Any chance of any breakfast?
I'll call the steward, sir.
Excellent!
And, er, who are you?
Leading Telegraphist Bowman, sir.
Jolly good. Er, nothing very elaborate, my dear. Just eggs, bacon, toast, coffee. Oh, and a little rough-cut marmalade, if they've got it. How long is he likely to be? Captain Hart, I mean.
I don't know, sir.
Oh, well, now, I tell you what. You get him on your jolly old wireless and ask him to come over here at the double, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Walker goes back into the office.

Dialogue.Line: Send a signal to Captain Hart. Tell him that a Mister Walker is here to see him.
Parliamentary Private Secretary.
Er, aye aye, sir.
I'll call the steward.
Ah, and get me the morning papers, will you, there's a good girl.
If I may ask, sir, what is the purpose of your visit?
Why, all those ships sinking. I've come down to clear it up for you. The Minister's put me in full charge.
This is our planet. My people ruled the Earth when man was only an ape.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is out of the bell.

Dialogue.Line: Your people went into hibernation and abandoned Earth to its fate.
Our astronomers predicted that a great catastrophe would end all life on the face of the Earth.
Yes, but the catastrophe that you predicted never happened. And the apes that you left behind on the surface to die became man.
You know our history?
Yes. Yes, I've encountered your people before. That is why I want to prevent a conflict that can only end in your destruction.
We shall destroy man and reclaim the planet. Already we have begun to sink his ships.
Yes, and already more ships are being sent to hunt you down.
The submarine? We have captured it.
You may win a few victories to begin with but eventually you're bound to lose.
There are many thousands of our people in hibernation in this base. We have other colonies hidden all round the world. We shall be the victors in the war against mankind.
But there's no need for a war. Why can't you share the planet?
That would be impossible.
The depths of the sea and those areas on Earth where man cannot live can be yours.
And man would agree to that?
There's a chance. Wouldn't it be better to try for a peace, than to launch yourself into a war that you cannot possibly win?
I will consider what you have said.
Let me return to the humans, and I will endeavour to make a peace for you.
Perhaps it would be possible.
No! The Doctor is your deadly enemy! He must be destroyed!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Walker sits at Hart's desk, stirring his tea.

Dialogue.Line: Captain Hart, there's only one way to deal with this problem. You have to attack. Ugh. Oh, pass me the sugar, my dear, will you?
My submarine is missing in that area. There's a chance that some of the crew may still be alive.
And what about the Doctor? He may still be alive down there too!
Yes.
Well, this is war, my dear, and war calls for sacrifice. Any chance of any more toast, my dear?
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blythe takes the toast rack and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Now, I've had a look at that UNIT file about the creatures that your friend the Doctor encountered in those caves. And do you know what happened? Brigadier Lethbridge Stewart blew the whole lot up.
Maybe, but I bet he didn't do it by risking the lives of his own men.
Well, that's as maybe, but our line is quite clear. Immediate retaliation with everything that we've got.
I'm sorry, sir. I don't agree.
Your opinion is quite immaterial, Captain Hart. The order's already been given. Ships are converging on this area from ports all over England.
You're throwing away the lives of the men in that submarine, sir!
And you'll probably killed the Doctor. Look, do you realise that that's murder?
Murder? War always is, my dear. Where on Earth's that girl with my toast?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Rear Admiral dictates a message from the lead ship of the flotilla.

Dialogue.Line: Make this to Ministry of Defence Navy. Special Task Force will be in position at thirteen fifty. That's all. Thank you.
I beg you not to listen to this man. He's the personification of evil.
The Master is our friend.
He wants only to provoke a war.
I do not! I came here to help you revive your people.
Why should you need his help?
Our hibernation unit is faulty.
And I can now repair it for you.
But why revive your people only to have them killed? Let me try and negotiate that peace for you.
As you did before, Doctor? The last time this man encountered your race, he tricked them. The humans destroyed them all.
Is that true?
Yes. I tried to make peace but I failed.
You see? He admits it. Man is weak. Your conquest will be easy.
Believe me, man is not weak. He's only too proficient at devising weapons of annihilation and using them.
He says man is weak. He says man is strong.
He's lying! He's trying to frighten you!
No. I do not think he lies. Perhaps it would be better to make peace. I shall have consider what you have said.
Don't trust him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor raises his right hand and the sea devil puts its own hand against it.
Meanwhile, the task force prepares for battle, readying torpedoes and gun batteries.

Dialogue.Line: Inform Ministry of Defence. Task Force now in position and ready to attack.
Aye, aye, sir.
Roger Task Force. Over and out.
What is it?
The Task Force is in position, sir.
Excellent! Cry havoc and let slip the dogs of war, hmm? Well, tell them to carry out their orders. The attack will go ahead now.
No! Look, please, you've got to do something! Can't you stop him?
I wish you'd reconsider, sir.
Captain Hart, I have full authority. Now, are you going to carry out my order or must I replace you with someone who will?
I'm sorry, Jo.
Commence attack.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: E124 comes hard a-port and the gunnery section gets busy.

Dialogue.Line: Urgent attack. In the bracket.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barrages of depth charges are fired and plumes of water are sent high into the air. No debris.

Dialogue.Line: You will negotiate a truce between my people and the humans.
If you'll release the submarine and its crew, yes, as a gesture of good faith.
Very well.
You are throwing away the control of this planet! The humans will never make peace with you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Boom! as a depth charge finds its target and sends everyone staggering. The barrage continues, knocking them to the floor.

Dialogue.Line: Is this the promised peace? Can't you see that the humans are determined to wipe you out?
You are right! These apes cannot be trusted! Take him away and kill him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is taken away down a dark passage as the barrage continues. He manages to get free of his escort just before a section of roof comes down on them. He goes back to one of the crushed reptiles, brushes off the sand and rock, and takes its weapon.

Dialogue.Line: Destroy the ships!
No! Send your people down to the lower level. They'll be safe there.
We must retaliate.
Not yet. If I am to revive your people, I need time.
What would you have us do?
Convince the humans that their attack has been a success.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Lieutenant Commander is scanning the attack area.

Dialogue.Line: Sir?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Admiral takes a look, and sees two dead reptiles floating in the water.

Dialogue.Line: Roger, Task Force.
Sir? Signal from Task Force. They report bodies and debris coming to the surface.
Bodies? Did they say
No, Miss, just the lizard things.
We can call off the attack now, sir.
Well, I'm not sure.
Look, you've probably killed the Doctor and all those sailors. Aren't you satisfied?
There is a chance there might be some survivors. Would you want it said that you unnecessarily endangered the lives of naval personnel, sir?
All right. Have it your own way.
Make to Task Force. Abandon attack.
(big grin) Aye, aye, sir.
Cease fire.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A wall monitor shows the position of four surface vessels.

Dialogue.Line: You see? My plan has worked.
We could still destroy their ships before they are out of range.
No, let them go. Let them think that they have won.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master and the chief reptile touch hands, or gloves.

Dialogue.Line: You will now revive the rest of my people.
Yes, but first the trigger mechanism on your reactivation unit is faulty. I need electronic equipment to build a new one.
And where will you obtain this?
The humans will provide it. We shall attack their base.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters a section containing a reptile lying on the floor and some electronic equipment, and a survival suit from the submarine. In an adjoining cell, the submarine's First Officer is trying to force open a door with a small porthole in it using just a small knife.

Dialogue.Line: Optimistic, Number One, but I admire your pluck. Here, give it to me.
Would you like to try, sir?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor appears in the port hole.

Dialogue.Line: Good afternoon, gentlemen. Er, look, would you mind keeping back for a moment? That is if you want to get out? Thank you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uses the sea devil weapon to blast open the door.

Dialogue.Line: Who the blazes are you?
Look, I've no time to explain now. Where are the rest of your men?
Still in the submarine.
Is the submarine still operational?
Should be.
They've ripped out the communicators and the escape gear, as you can see.
But left the engines alone.
Yes.
Where's the sub now?
In a kind of undersea harbour.
Can you find the way?
I think so, yes.
Right, you'd better lead on. Here, take this. It's a gun. Now come on, let's hurry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One reptile is standing guard as the crewmen play pontoon.

Dialogue.Line: What about you, Chris?
I'll stick.
You?
Twist. I'll stick.
Right. Ha! Pay twenties.
Eighteen,
Nineteen. Well, that's it then. You've cleared me right out.
What about you? Do you want to go on?
Not bothered.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a banging on the hull. Rhythmic, morse code type banging.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
Er, loose rigging.
Rigging?
Yeah, what about a game of consequences? Yeah, I'll start.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Summers writes on a pad until the banging stops, then hands the paper to Girton.

Dialogue.Line: Right, it's your turn. Er, you've got to do what it says there.
That's not how you play consequences.
It's the way we play.
Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Girton clutches his stomach and groans. Summers gestures him to get louder.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter with him?
He's throwing a fit!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The reptile comes over.

Dialogue.Line: Here, can't you see? He's not well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The reptile bends to look at Girton's face. Summers and Lovell attack but are thrown off as Ridgeway, with the weapon, and the Doctor come down the ladder.

Dialogue.Line: No, no! Don't kill him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ridgeway fires anyway.

Dialogue.Line: There's no need to have done that!
Any more of them, Summers?
Yes, there's some more on guard up top, sir.
We've dealt with them already. Right, action stations! We're getting under way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ridgeway tosses the weapon over his shoulder to Mitchell.

Dialogue.Line: Aye, aye, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Back at the detention area the reptile wakes and sees that the two officers have broken out of their cell. It raises the alarm as the submarine's propeller starts turning.

Dialogue.Line: The humans have escaped.
The submarine! They'll try to recapture it.
Activate the force field!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The submarine is part way out of a rock face cave when the bright forcefield comes on.

Dialogue.Line: Sir, we've stopped moving.
Increase revolutions.
Maximum revs, sir.
They're holding us back with some kind of force field.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The monitor shows the submarine being pushed back through the rock face.

Dialogue.Line: They cannot escape us now.
There must be something we can do?
Well, you could try firing your torpedoes at the cave wall and blasting yourselves free.
We're still halfway in the cave, sir. We could blow ourselves up.
That's a risk you'll have to take.
Forward ends, this is the Captain. Load all bow tubes. Open one and two bow caps.
Increase the force field.
The engines. We're losing power.
Well, hurry up and fire those torpedoes, or we'll be drawn back into the cave.
All bow heads open. Ready to fire, sir.
Well, come on, man! You've got to risk it!
Stand by bow salvo.
Standing by, sir.
Fire one. Fire two.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Boom! and the submarine shoots backwards out of the cave.

Dialogue.Line: Increase the force field. They must not escape.
It's no use. You're already too late.
Any damage forward, Chief?
No damage to tell, sir.
Thank you. All right, stand by to surface, Number One. MITCHELL: Aye, aye, sir.
We're going home.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The monitor shows the submarine making good speed.

Dialogue.Line: They can tell the humans how to find our base.
It's of no importance. Before they can attack us we shall attack them.
Doctor! I thought you were dead!
Dead? No, I don't think so.
When I saw that thing come up empty, I thought I'd never see you again.
Well, well, well, so the heroes have returned.
Captain Hart, what idiot ordered an all out attack just as I was on the verge of finding a peaceful solution?
But it wasn't Captain Hart's fault. It was this
I'm terribly sorry. This is Mister Walker. He's the Parliamentary Private Secretary in charge of this business.
I'm the idiot you've just been talking about. Absolutely splendid lunch, old man.
You ordered the attack?
I did.
Did you give any thought at all, sir, as to what you were doing?
Our duty is to destroy the Queen's enemies. Don't you know your national anthem? Confound their politics, frustrate their knavish tricks.
That, sir, is an extremely insular point of view. At the precise moment of the attack, I was negotiating a peace.
Peace? Huh. What, when they've been attacking our shipping and heaven alone knows what? I think you've got it all wrong, old man. Seek and destroy. That's what you chaps say, isn't it?
But the point, Mister Parliamentary Private Secretary, is that you have not destroyed. You have just made them angry. Very, very angry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: So angry that hordes of reptiles are now emerging from the sea, taking out the lone sentry on the beach and making their way through the base unopposed.

Dialogue.Line: I'm going to get on to the Minister, and I'm going to ask him to seek approval for an immediate attack with nuclear weapons.
But that, sir, would be tantamount to murder.
Oh, come, come, Doctor. You speak as if these creatures are human. We're not going to hand over the world to a lot of lizards, you know.
You can share it with them, surely?
Oh, come. Really, Doctor.
Look, let me make one final attempt to negotiate.
Well, you didn't get very far last time, did you?

Just you think of it, sir. Think of it. Wouldn't you like to be the man behind a peaceful settlement? Walker the peacemaker, they'd call you. Or would you prefer to be known as the man responsible for launching a full scale war!
Look, you can actually communicate with these creatures?
Yes.
And you'd be willing to undertake the preliminary negotiations yourself?
Just leave it to me.
Doctor, you're not thinking of going down there again?
Jo, it's the only way.
But, Doctor, it's far too dangerous!
Don't you understand, Jo? I've got to go down there of my own free will as a gesture of good faith. Captain Hart, is that diving vessel still alongside?
Yes, but I must say that I agree with Miss Grant.
Then with your permission, Mister Walker? (to Blythe) My cape.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Without hesitation, the Doctor runs to the reptile, knocks the weapon out of its hand and slams its head against a nearby wall. A second reptile gets a double-handed punch to the midsection then jaw.

Dialogue.Line: All right, Captain Hart, get these two out of here.
Doctor, look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another reptile grabs the Doctor's neck from behind and puts pressure on. He blacks out. More reptiles arrive and raise their weapons.

Dialogue.Line: No! No, take them inside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart and Jo half-carry the Doctor back to the main building.

Dialogue.Line: Dear, oh dear, Doctor. Will you never learn?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: All over the base, naval personnel are being rounded up and shut in building 289.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Doctor, for your information the capture of this naval base is the first step in the return of this planet to its rightful owners. Right, bring him in, will you?
How do you hope to achieve that?
As you know, our friends here have underground and underwater bases all over the world. Well, I propose to reactivate them.
You haven't reactivated them yet, have you.
Er, not yet, no. But I can, with your help.
I wondered why I was still alive.
I advise you not to give me any trouble, Doctor. Not if you value the life of every man on this base.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart tries the radio.

Dialogue.Line: It's no good! They've cut the power supply!
Shush! Look, there's still some of them in there.
This is monstrous! What are you going to do about it, Captain Hart?
Captain Hart, what about this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo points at a hatch in the ceiling.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, we should be able to open it. But I could never get through the ventilation shaft up there.
No, but I could.
The table.
Right.
Here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They clear equipment from a table.

Dialogue.Line: What, what are you doing?
We are going to put this table underneath that ventilation hatch and try to open it.
Yes, but supposing you get caught? They might take reprisals against the innocent!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart climbs onto the table.

Dialogue.Line: A screwdriver. Jo, over there on the bench somewhere.
Right.
Don't you think we ought to leave these things to the Doctor? He said we ought to cooperate with them, you know?
Tool kit. Underneath. Underneath the bench.
Look, he's, er, he's not going to try and trick them, is he?
Shush!
That's it.
This could have the most dreadful consequences! He, he, he made them a promise, you know.
Yes, in order to save our lives! Now do you mind?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master gets their reptile escort to wait outside.

Dialogue.Line: Now then, Doctor, my problem is this. During millions of years of hibernation, the reactivation machinery has deteriorated. I now find it necessary to build a trigger mechanism for it.
And how do you hope to do that?
Well, by constructing a sonar device analogous to the laser. With this, I can not only pinpoint and revive the base by the sea fort, but every other base in the world.
And you've convinced your reptilian friends that this will work?
You know it'll work, with your cooperation. All the equipment we need is here.
Hmm. Yes, I suppose it's possible.
I've drawn up some preliminary plans here. There.
Good grief! What on Earth do you think you're doing?
Why? What is the matter?
Well, this circuit here, it's completely misplaced. And also you'll need far more power through to your main dipode. Give me a pencil, will you?
There you are.
Thank you.
And you think you can correct this fault?
Yes, I think so, given time. Now then, let's see.
Are you, are you really going to let a mere child risk her life?
Well I could never get through that ventilation shaft. Would you like to try? Come on, Jo. Now, once you're through the shaft, there's a hatch that comes out onto the roof of this building.
Okay.
Are you ready? Hup.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart lifts Jo into the shaft.

Dialogue.Line: That's it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo drags herself along on her stomach to the grill on the roof amidst an array of aerials, and radar and microwave dishes. Avoiding a pair of reptiles she climbs down a ladder to the ground and runs through the base until she sees something through the window of -
The Master is working on the device and the Doctor is collecting parts. He pauses for a moment when he sees something at the window, then carries on.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Oh, I need a polarising condenser.
Oh, allow me.
Oh, thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master goes to the rear room of the stores. Jo lifts the upper part of the window.

Dialogue.Line: (sotto) Come on, Doctor! Hurry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor checks that the Master is out of sight then goes to the window.

Dialogue.Line: (sotto) Come on!
Now Jo, listen to me. In a few minutes time, I'm going to create a diversion. Now, as soon as it starts, you try and get Hart and the others out.
But what about the guards?
Don't worry about the guards. You leave them to me. Now, you hurry back there and wait for the off.
Okay.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor returns to the workbench. Jo starts to run back to the main building, but has to turn and run the other way as a reptile patrol approaches. A little while later, the trigger mechanism is about complete.

Dialogue.Line: All right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor plugs it in to the mains. Jo is back in the main building. A reptile enters the stores.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Doctor?
How about a little test? Right, here goes. (The Doctor switches it on and the reptile clutches its head in agony.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: So does the one in Hart's office so Jo runs through and opens the radio room door to release Hart and Walker.

Dialogue.Line: What the blazes?
The Doctor's doing it. Now come on, quickly, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Walker can't bring himself to push past the suffering reptile, and goes back into the radio room.
Hart and Jo leave the main building, past two more writhing reptiles. They come across a fallen Marine and Hart takes his rifle.

Dialogue.Line: We must find the hovercraft pilot. JO: It's all right. I can fly one. Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A hovercraft - SRN5 - is sitting on the shingle. Hart shoots at a group of approaching reptiles while Jo gets into the pilot's seat and starts it up. He manages to kill them before the hovercraft's skirts inflate and they glide down onto the sea.

Dialogue.Line: Switch the power off!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master pulls the plug out of the wall and the reptile stands still.

Dialogue.Line: What happened?
I must have had the frequency too high. I'm sorry about that. Oh, no, I see what it is. I had the output jack in the input socket. There. Yeah, there that should work all right now.
We shan't know for sure till we get it back to their base and build it into their power system.
We?
Yes, Doctor. You're coming with me.
Oh, I see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The reptile leader is escorted in.

Dialogue.Line: This noise, what has been happening?
Teething troubles, that's all.
It must not happen again. Is the work completed?
Yes, I've now finished.
Then we shall return to our base. Do you want him killed now?
No. He might yet prove useful. Well, Doctor? Shall we go?
If you insist.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The leader sees the hovercraft heading for the base.

Dialogue.Line: Guard them. Keep them safe. I must alert the others.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master and the Doctor are locked back in the stores. The hovercraft lands and Hart leads a troop of marines onto the beach and the battle for the base begins. Despite the difference in weaponry, the marines have the upper hand and are cutting down reptiles far more quickly than they take casualties of their own.

Dialogue.Line: Well, it seems as if things aren't quite going according to plan.
Look, we must break out of here! I've got to get this device down to your base.
Myers, check that storeroom!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The reptile puts the Master behind him as the door opens and a Petty Officer looks in.

Dialogue.Line: Looks all right.
Look out behind you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Myers puts five rounds rapid into the reptile.

Dialogue.Line: Would one of you gentlemen be the Doctor?
Yes, I am. This man is an extremely dangerous criminal, so guard him well. Now, have you seen Captain Hart and Miss Grant?
I'm not sure, sir.
Right, I'd better go and find them.
Right, I'll stay with this bloke.
Yeah, do that. And watch him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves. Myers keeps his rifle leveled at the Master.

Dialogue.Line: There's been a misunderstanding here, you know. I'm not the man that you want. There's been a mistake.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Myers gets treated to a full Look.

Dialogue.Line: You understand? A mistake.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master pushes the rifle barrel aside and hits Myers hard.

Dialogue.Line: A mistake!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hart and a rating load a two inch gun emplacement and use it against a troop of reptiles. The Doctor arrives.

Dialogue.Line: Have you seen Jo Grant anywhere?
She's on the beach.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sees the Master run through the gate onto the beach, carrying the trigger mechanism.

There are a pair of bright orange one-man jet boats just above the surf line. The Master puts the mechanism in one and launches it. The Doctor runs down the beach to the second and launches that, giving chase. The reptile leader and his surviving warriors run into the sea. The Master beaches his craft on another sandy beach and the Doctor catches up to him.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master points to a reptile diving bell, then six reptiles come over the dunes.

Dialogue.Line: Now, perhaps you'll admit I was right all along. Massive nuclear strike. It's the only way.
But not until we know what's happened to the Doctor.
Excuse me, sir. I've just seen Lieutenant Scott. He said he saw the Doctor heading out to sea.
Ha ha, gone to join his friends. Gone over to the other side.
He seemed to be chasing another boat.
He must have been after the Master.

Well, be that as it may, they'll both have to take their chances. I'm going to put an end to these creatures right away. Kindly get me the Minister on the phone. I'm going to request that we launch a nuclear strike. Now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master and the Doctor are attaching the trigger mechanism to the reptile's hibernation equipment.

Dialogue.Line: We want revenge on the human species. Many of my people have been killed.
It was a necessary sacrifice.
You said man was weak.
So he is. Soon you will surge from the seas in your millions and exterminate him.
Don't listen to him. Why begin a long and bloody war where thousands will be killed on both sides?
We shall destroy man and reclaim the planet.
Is there nothing I can say to make you reconsider?
Nothing!
I'm sorry.
Is the machine ready?
It is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor adjusts a lever on the top.

Dialogue.Line: Then activate it.
Allow me, Doctor. We don't want any accidents this time.
The power may take some time to build up, you know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master switches the trigger mechanism on.

Dialogue.Line: I suggest you now dispose of this man.
Take them both to the cages.
What's the meaning of this? I'm your ally!
Both, I say! Take them!
I helped you! I helped you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An armada of surface vessels and submarines are approaching the Solent.

Dialogue.Line: Look, I demand you take me back to your chief! Immediately!
You seem to be losing your touch.
Once they see that the device works properly, they'll release me.
I very much doubt it. You see, before you reactivated it, I reversed the polarity of the neutron flow.
You did what? You realise what will happen?
Oh, yes. Do you?
Well, there'll be a massive reverse feedback into their whole power system.
Exactly. In about ten minutes from now the whole place should go up. Enjoy your revenge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master goes to the small porthole and shouts out.

Dialogue.Line: Guards! Guards, come back! You must release me! I must talk to your chief! Let me out! We're all in danger! Let me out!
You're wasting your time, you know. Even if they heard you, they couldn't do anything about it.
Why?
Well, I built a self-destruct mechanism into the main control switch. You can't turn it off.
But but we'll both be killed.
That's right. Unless we can both escape.
Ships moving into position now, sir.
Very well. This time we'll continue the attack until those creatures are finally destroyed. Now, how about some tea?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uses his sonic screwdriver to unlock the cell.

Dialogue.Line: You see? Come on.
Well, just as I told you. Submarine escape equipment. Now, all we've got to do is find the airlock.
Airlock?
Yes, there must be one around here somewhere. Otherwise how else did we get down in those capsules? Here you are. Put this on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blythe enters with Walker's lunch on a heavy tray.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, thank you, my dear. Ah ha! Smoked salmon. Delicious.
Won't be long now.
Suppose the Doctor manages to escape from that place?
Not much chance, I'm afraid.
Yes, but just suppose?
Get a high speed hovercraft over that area. I want a complete sweep before the attack.
Aye, aye, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two figures in orange survival suits are bobbing up and down in the sea, waving. The crew of XT492 pull the Master aboard.

Dialogue.Line: All right?
All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Then it is the Doctor's turn.
The power in the trigger mechanism builds towards maximum.

Dialogue.Line: This device is causing the power to overload.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He switches it off, and there is a little bang.
Safely inside the craft, the Master clutches his chest and falls to the floor. Then something under the sea goes KaBOOM several times.

Dialogue.Line: Large underwater explosion reported, sir.
What? Has the attack started already?
No, sir, before the attack. And they've picked up two survivors. One of them was in a bad way. They've radioed for an ambulance to stand by.
Did they, did they say who?
No, Miss.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: SRN5 lands as Jo and a pair of stretcher bearers run down the shingle. The Doctor goes to meet Jo and Hart.

Dialogue.Line: They said someone was hurt?
It's the Master. He collapsed soon after they picked us up.
Well then, Doctor, what happened?
I managed to destroy their base for you.
Thank goodness. Well done.
Well, I did what I had to to prevent a war.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The stretcher party come back with the Master.

Dialogue.Line: He's dead.
We were too late. The doctor in the hovercraft said so.
Doctor? What doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor removes a latex mask from the man on the stretcher.

Dialogue.Line: I must obey. I must obey. I must obey. I must obey. I must obey. I must obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master flies the hovercraft back out to sea.

Dialogue.Line: I must obey. I must obey.
